subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: how to transcribe air and ear
msgSnippet: ... That s a peculiarity of North American English: t and d between vowels are pronounced the same way.  In the rest of the anglophone world that is not
messageBody:
Paul Tremblay scripsit:

> Yes, again of course there are two phonemes. Does it really matter to me
> that the second sound has variations? My professor told me his
> daughter was giving "writing" lessons. I had had his daughter as a
> student the semester before, and I couldn't believe she had enough
> ability to teach writing. But he meant "ridding," which is pronouced the
> same exact way in speech. So what?

That's a peculiarity of North American English: "t" and "d" between vowels are
pronounced the same way. In the rest of the anglophone world that is not true.

> But language is spoken, so of course it is important how the phonemes
> present themselves in sound. I mean, if I am a farmer and I tell my son
> to go kill the hog, I had better hope he doesn't kill the dog. In that
> case, the phonemes are not abstract but very concrete!

They are still abstract, although /h/ and /d/ happen to be pronounced
pretty uniformly in English. Miscommunication becomes much more
serious in the Ian/Ann case, or when I say "go buy a mitt" and
you come back with a mutt (in the Inland North U.S.) or vice versa
(in New Zealand).

--
